name: Secura

oscp_relevance.reasoning: Comprehensive 3-machine Active Directory chain demonstrating critical OSCP skills: credential extraction with Mimikatz, local vs domain authentication distinction, Chisel tunneling for localhost-bound services, MySQL credential harvesting, and GPO abuse for domain privilege escalation. Multi-machine pivoting and credential reuse patterns are highly exam-relevant.

synopsis: Secura is a 3-machine Active Directory challenge lab demonstrating a complete enterprise attack chain. Initial access is gained through ManageEngine AppManager on SECURE (.95), where Mimikatz extracts credentials including a local account for ERA. The apache credential enables WinRM access to ERA (.96), but MySQL is bound to localhost only - requiring Chisel reverse tunneling to enumerate the database remotely. MySQL contains plaintext credentials for 'administrator' and 'charlotte'. Charlotte's credentials provide low-privilege access to DC01 (.97), where insecure GPO permissions allow adding charlotte to local Administrators via SharpGPOAbuse. Critical lesson: Windows tokens require session refresh after group membership changes.

learned: Chisel reverse port forwarding for localhost-bound services
Mimikatz non-interactive execution for constrained shells
Windows token refresh after group membership changes

attack_phases.description: Initial reconnaissance of all three machines reveals distinct attack surfaces: SECURE hosts ManageEngine AppManager (8443), ERA runs MariaDB (3306), and DC01 provides standard AD services. All machines have WinRM (5985) enabled for remote management.

commands_used.context: Initial TCP port discovery across all three target machines
commands_used.notes: Scan all machines simultaneously for efficiency. Identified ManageEngine on .95 as primary attack vector.

commands_used.context: Detailed service enumeration on discovered ports
commands_used.notes: ManageEngine AppManager identified - known CVE target

key_findings: ManageEngine AppManager on SECURE:8443 - high-value exploitation target
MariaDB 10.3.24 on ERA:3306 - potential credential storage
All machines have WinRM enabled - enables PowerShell remoting with valid credentials
DC01 is domain controller for secura.yzx domain
attack_phases.oscp_notes: Multi-machine enumeration strategy: scan all targets first to identify path of least resistance. ManageEngine products frequently have CVEs. WinRM on all machines suggests credential-based lateral movement will be key.

attack_phases.description: Initial foothold obtained on SECURE (.95) through ManageEngine AppManager Actions Admin interface exploitation. Post-exploitation with Mimikatz revealed credentials for the ERA machine stored in Credential Manager, plus domain user credentials.

vulnerabilities.name: ManageEngine AppManager - Actions Admin File Upload
vulnerabilities.notes: Uploaded shell.bat containing PowerShell reverse shell via Actions Admin functionality

commands_used.context: Extract credentials from LSASS memory after gaining Administrator access
commands_used.notes: Non-interactive execution required for evil-winrm session. Combined sekurlsa and vault commands to dump both LSASS and Credential Manager.

commands_used.context: Collect Active Directory data for BloodHound analysis
commands_used.notes: BloodHound data helps identify privilege escalation paths

key_findings: apache:New2Era4.! stored in Credential Manager for era.secura.local
Credential Manager entry referenced 'era.secura.local' hostname - indicates LOCAL account, not domain
attack_phases.oscp_notes: Non-interactive Mimikatz is essential for constrained shells. The command sequence pattern 'cmd1' 'cmd2' 'exit' works with evil-winrm. Credential Manager stores can reveal lateral movement paths - the 'era.secura.local' entry was the key to the next machine.

attack_phases.description: Lateral movement to ERA (.96) required understanding local vs domain authentication. After WinRM access as apache, MySQL was only accessible via localhost - Chisel reverse tunnel enabled remote enumeration from Kali. MySQL 'creds' database contained plaintext passwords for administrator and charlotte.

commands_used.context: Test apache credentials with local authentication after domain auth failed
commands_used.notes: Local auth succeeded where domain auth failed - apache was a LOCAL account on ERA

commands_used.context: Establish interactive shell on ERA as apache
Start Chisel server on Kali to receive reverse tunnel from ERA
commands_used.notes: Reverse mode required because ERA cannot directly connect to Kali on arbitrary ports

commands_used.context: Establish reverse tunnel from ERA to forward MySQL port to Kali
commands_used.notes: R:3306:127.0.0.1:3306 means: Kali listens on 3306, forwards to ERA's localhost:3306

commands_used.context: Connect to MySQL through Chisel tunnel - root with no password (XAMPP default)
commands_used.notes: XAMPP default: MySQL root has no password. Always test default credentials on dev stacks.

commands_used.context: Escalate to administrator using credentials from MySQL dump

failed_attempts.actual: ERROR 1130 (HY000): Host 'KALI_IP' is not allowed to connect to this MariaDB server
failed_attempts.reason: MySQL configured with host-based ACLs restricting connections to localhost only
failed_attempts.solution: Use Chisel reverse port forwarding to tunnel MySQL traffic through localhost
failed_attempts.lesson_learned: MySQL/MariaDB commonly binds to 127.0.0.1 for security. Always use tunneling (Chisel, SSH, ligolo-ng) when services are localhost-only.

failed_attempts.reason: Apache was a LOCAL account on ERA, not a domain account. Credential Manager entry referenced 'era.secura.local' (hostname), not the domain.
failed_attempts.solution: Use --local-auth flag with crackmapexec for local accounts
failed_attempts.lesson_learned: ALWAYS try both --local-auth and domain authentication. Credential Manager entries referencing hostnames (machine.domain) indicate LOCAL accounts, not domain accounts.

key_findings: MySQL 'creds' database contained plaintext credentials table
MySQL root had no password (XAMPP default configuration)
attack_phases.oscp_notes: Chisel is essential for OSCP when services bind to localhost. The pattern: Kali runs 'chisel server --reverse', target runs 'chisel client R:PORT:127.0.0.1:PORT'. Database credentials often match system accounts - always test MySQL passwords against WinRM/SSH.

attack_phases.description: Domain privilege escalation on DC01 (.97) via GPO abuse. Charlotte had Full Control (F) permissions on the Default Domain Policy GPO. SharpGPOAbuse added charlotte to local Administrators, but a critical lesson emerged: Windows access tokens require session refresh after group membership changes.

vulnerabilities.name: Insecure GPO Permissions
vulnerabilities.notes: charlotte user has Full Control (F) on Default Domain Policy - applies to ALL domain computers

commands_used.context: Initial access to DC01 as charlotte domain user
Enumerate GPO permissions in SYSVOL to find writable policies
commands_used.notes: Charlotte has Full Control (F) on Default Domain Policy - immediate privesc path

commands_used.context: Abuse GPO write permissions to add charlotte to local Administrators
Force immediate GPO refresh to apply changes
Verify charlotte was added to local Administrators group
commands_used.notes: Charlotte now in Administrators group, but current session token NOT updated

commands_used.context: Reconnect to get new access token with admin privileges
commands_used.notes: New session required - Windows tokens created at logon don't update dynamically

failed_attempts.attempt: Access Administrator resources after GPO update without re-login
failed_attempts.actual: Only BUILTIN\Remote Management Users and BUILTIN\Users shown
failed_attempts.reason: Windows access tokens are created at logon. Group membership changes via GPO don't affect existing session tokens.
failed_attempts.solution: Exit current session completely and reconnect to receive new token with updated group membership
failed_attempts.lesson_learned: Windows token model: group membership != token groups. After ANY group change (GPO, net localgroup, etc.), MUST start NEW session to get updated privileges. This is a common exam mistake.

key_findings: charlotte has Full Control (F) on Default Domain Policy
Default Domain Policy applies to ALL domain computers - immediate domain-wide admin
Token refresh required after group membership changes
attack_phases.oscp_notes: GPO abuse is a HIGH-VALUE OSCP technique. Always check SYSVOL with icacls - misconfigured GPO permissions are common. The Default Domain Policy ({31B2F340-...}) applies EVERYWHERE. Token refresh gotcha is a frequent exam stumbling block - always reconnect after group changes.

key_learnings.detail: Credential Manager entries referencing hostnames (era.secura.local) indicate LOCAL accounts, not domain accounts. Always try both --local-auth and domain authentication with crackmapexec. Domain auth failure doesn't mean invalid credentials - the account may simply be local.
key_learnings.methodology: When credentials found: 1) Try domain auth, 2) Try --local-auth, 3) Check credential source for hostname vs domain references

key_learnings.detail: MySQL/MariaDB and other services commonly bind to 127.0.0.1 for security. Chisel reverse port forwarding (R:PORT:127.0.0.1:PORT) tunnels traffic through the target's localhost. Server on Kali, client on target. Essential when direct connection returns 'host not allowed'.
key_learnings.time_impact: Chisel setup: 2-3 minutes vs hours of alternative approaches
key_learnings.methodology: Pattern: 1) Kali: chisel server -p 8080 --reverse, 2) Target: chisel client KALI:8080 R:LOCAL_PORT:127.0.0.1:TARGET_PORT

key_learnings.detail: XAMPP, WAMP, and similar development stacks commonly ship MySQL with root having NO password. Always test default credentials (root:blank, root:root, root:mysql) on any MySQL/MariaDB service. Database credentials frequently match system account passwords.
key_learnings.methodology: MySQL found? Try: mysql -u root (no -p), then search for credential tables: SELECT * FROM information_schema.columns WHERE column_name LIKE '%pass%'

key_learnings.detail: Check SYSVOL ACLs with icacls on every AD engagement. Full Control (F) or Write (W) on a GPO = immediate privilege escalation path. Default Domain Policy ({31B2F340-...}) applies to ALL domain computers. SharpGPOAbuse --AddLocalAdmin is the fastest exploitation path.
key_learnings.methodology: icacls "\\DOMAIN\SYSVOL\DOMAIN\Policies\*" - look for (F), (W), or (M) on your user

key_learnings.lesson: Token Refresh After Group Membership Changes
key_learnings.detail: Windows access tokens are created at logon and contain group membership at that moment. Adding user to Administrators via GPO, net localgroup, or other methods does NOT update the current session's token. MUST exit session and reconnect to receive new token with updated privileges.
key_learnings.time_impact: Common 10-15 minute exam time waste if not understood
key_learnings.methodology: After group change: 1) Verify with 'net localgroup administrators', 2) Exit session completely, 3) Reconnect, 4) Verify with 'whoami /groups'

key_learnings.detail: Evil-WinRM and other constrained shells don't support interactive prompts. Run Mimikatz with command-line arguments: .\mimi.exe "cmd1" "cmd2" "exit". Commands execute sequentially. Combine sekurlsa::logonpasswords with vault::cred /patch for comprehensive credential extraction.

references.name: Chisel
references.description: TCP/UDP tunnel over HTTP with reverse and forward modes

references.name: SharpGPOAbuse
references.description: GPO abuse tool for adding local admins, scheduled tasks, etc.
Microsoft documentation on Default Domain Policy
